Bassman

In a 75-25 Senate vote, Democrats failed to filibuster the up or down vote on Apellate Judge Samuel A. Alito to the United States Supreme Court to succeed retiring Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. With the full vote scheduled for Tuesday, it looks like Alito will be confirmed. Now if we can only get that sellout Kennedy or Ruth Vader Ginsburg to retire, then the daunting task of reparing the damage of the last 35 or so years will begin. Your thoughts?

post_info.post_title: Filibuster flatline and the imminent confirmation of Alito.

jyoshu

I have to say I agree for the most part.
 
 Filabusters should, as the 'gang of 14' says, be used for extraordinary situations. Alito is a qualified judge for the position. He's declared he will judge impartially. 
 
 Normally, I don't care for the Democratic senator Robert Byrd's views. But he nailed it when he said . . .
 "A better understanding of the Court's role would do much to diminish the "hype" that now accompanies the judicial nomination process. The role of the Senate in the Alito debate is not to push legislation, or to score points for those who either support or oppose specific legislative proposals. The purpose of the current debate is to evaluate the fitness of Judge Samuel Alito to sit on the highest Court of our land which includes his temperament and his intellectual ability...
 
 I know not exactly what kind of Justice Samuel Alito may actually be - - no one does. But my considered judgment from his record, from his answers to my questions, and from his obvious intelligence and sincerity, leads me to believe him to be an honorable man, who loves his country, loves his Constitution, and will give of his best. Can we really ask for more?"
Bassman

 Something I thought was interesting that was brought out in the trial, is that it's not Republicans that tend to try and stack the Court with idealogues because Republicans have overwhelmingly voted pro-choice candidates in. Using abortion as a litmus test has become a Democrat thing. It's another way they've moved too far from center. They wouldn't put a pro-life speaker on the list at their conventions, but Republicans had several pro-choice speakers at theirs.

Scalia, Thomas, and Roberts have proven to be reliable conservatives. Let's hope Alito doen't get caught up in the Washington "culture" or he'll sell out like Kennedy.

 By some accounts, the Republicans have been stacking the SC with nominees

The filibuster, when used right , can be a useful tool, but the Dem. use it too much. They had their chance to pick Alito apart in the hearings, but chose to ask questions that Alito had no problem in avoiding.

 
 I too was surprised that there were several controversial issues that never came up in the hearings, that I know of. It was mostly senators using it for a soapbox for their view on the abortion issue, and some on executive privilege.
 
 But at the same time, it's not whether a candidate is left or right in his ideology that should matter, but whether he/she is too extreme one way or the other, and whether or not they would be a fair, objective judge. I saw nothing in Alito that would indicate he is an extremist or would judge unfairly.

No, according to the U.S. Constitution those serving on the Supreme Court can be impeached.
 
 It's never been done before, but there's no reason why there couldn't be a first time.
 
 Article. III. Section. 1.
